explanation: based on the provided data, planting peaches appears to be the most profitable option. the average peach yield in california is 13.7 tons per acre with an average price of $763 per ton. over 10 acres, this would result in an expected yield of 137 tons and an expected revenue of $104,511 (137 tons * $763 per ton). in comparison, grapefruit has an average yield of 457 boxes per acre at $24.33 per box, which would result in a revenue of $111,150.1 over 10 acres, but grapefruit production has been significantly affected by winter storm uri, reducing the crop to half the predicted volume, which could potentially halve the revenue. lemons have an average yield of 428 boxes per acre at $23.3 per box, resulting in a revenue of $99,724 over 10 acres, but production is at its lowest in five years due to heat damage. pears have an average yield of 15.6 tons per acre at $565 per ton, resulting in a revenue of $88,020 over 10 acres, but the impact of the northwest heat wave on production levels is still uncertain. considering the higher expected revenue without the significant risks that other crops are facing, peaches are the recommended crop to plant on your 10 acres of land.
